Working on GitHub (a web based hosting service) was an entirely new experience in working on a versioning system. Now that I feel more confident in ruling over the black prompt monster, I gathered loads of " take note of" features that I want to share.
The homogeneity, dynamic-ness and the multi level backup options that Git provides, are some of the things which grasped my attention and interest.
After registering and creating a GitHub account I used the SSH key generated to successfully link the two.
Then I moved on to creating a repository following the well instructed simple steps from : http://help.github.com .
Further on I juggled around trying to 
- push and pull files into and from repository,
- push and pull repository,
- add collaborators
- merge files and resolve conflicts,
- fork and upstream repository
- creating branches and organization.
A few finer features of Github that I noticed are as follows:
1) A collaborator cannot add another user as a collaborator, although rest of its rights are at par with the admin.
i.e. Only an Admin can add a collaborator
2) In an organisation any owner or admin can add another owner, unlike a collaborator.
I feel besides forking, these are two unique combination of features that git offers its user, which helps admin to restrict level of access to different users.
Following are some of the features in branching a repository , which I feel may be a bit tricky for a first timer:
1) Both admin and collaborator can create a branch in a repository
2) When you clone a repository, only the master directory gets cloned.
i.e. After you clone a repository, if you run the following command :
$git branch - You will get only the master branch directory, irrespective of the number of branches that the repository has at the GitHub server.
3) If you want to switch to any other branch of a cloned repository, then you need   to execute command: git checkout -b branchname origin/branch name

4) When you create a branch in a repository: If the master branch had some files.Then those files are also copied into the newly created child branch. 
But after the creation of the branch, if further files are added to the master branch (that is like a parent here) ,Then those files DO NOT get added in the branches of the repository.
As a good practice always remember to do a $ git pull and ensure that your code is updated before git push.
Two confusing commands I frequently came across was Git pull and Git Fetch.
Difference between Git pull and Git Fetch :
- On doing git pull, if you have conflicts between the files in the local repository and server repository you get merge options and it auto-merges as much as possible.
- In case of fetch, auto merging does not happen.
On doing a Git Status, one often gets a message like :
$ git status
# On branch master
# Your branch is ahead of 'origin/master' by 1 commit.
#
# Changed but not updated:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
#   (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
#
# modified:   lib/simplegit.rb
-This means that you local machine stage has 1 more commits (or 1 version code ahead) of the GitHub server repository. You need to check and then push your commits to come be in sync.

Many times when I tried pushing code I found Fatal 403 error. This I figured out was because Hyper Text Transfer Protocol Secure (HTTPS) is a secure version of the Hyper Text Transfer Protocol (http).
To add origin I was using the following:
$ git remote add origin https://github.com/username.git -which gave me the error
So I would suggest, as a best practice, to use the following:
$ git remote add origin git@github.com:username/Hello-World.git

In case we have already added using secure url then we can remove origin and re-initialize it:
$ git remote rm origin (Removes current origin )
$ git remote -v (This lists all the remote origin)
$ git remote add origin git@github.com:username/Hello-World.git
I also noticed that when I initialised using : 
$ git remote add origin git@github.com:username/Hello-World.git instead of $ git remote add origin https://github.com/username.git , I was not asked for my credentials while pushing data from local working machine to GitHub repository.
This is because this acts as url mapped with the SSH key and thus is synced with our account and hence does not need our credential again.
Even while trying to clone a repository, the thumb rule of using the SSH key generated Url holds good.
